tweets.text:
This is interesting. I'll play.

One like = one opinion on energy system transformation.

Capped at 100. And no time limit - don't want to get all obsessed over here. https://t.co/DVGgR2x5a8

1/ Despite huge transformation in generation and networks, ordinary people haven't seen any real change in how they engage with energy. Consumer participation in and interaction with energy systems will change everything - and has just barely started.

h/t @guynewey

2/ Deployment of electric vehicles is so exciting because it's the first example of an at-scale energy resource that can shift its demand in both space and time. 

That presents a huge risk if EV behaviour is poorly managed, or a huge opportunity if we get the incentives right.
You'll need to like the main tweet if you want an opinion, @GuyLipman í ½í¸‰

3/ One of the biggest challenges facing utilities is the digital transformation. Marconi wouldn't recognise the modern telecomms systems; Edison would recognise modern power systems. Utilities will need to become data businesses that also do energy.

4/ Linked to 3: strategic workforce planning and cultural design will make or break utilities of the future. If you're used to employing power system engineers who stay for decades, how will you attract and retain young and mobile data scientists?

https://t.co/z0mV7lYvCP

5/ There's nothing intrinsically bad about nuclear power, particularly from a climate perspective, but we've forgotten how to build nuclear plants on time and at a sensible price. We should extend the lives of existing plants, but not build any more until we've figured those out.

6/ I suspect we've done so well decarbonising electricity partly as constructive procrastination around decarbonising heat. You can argue that one requires the other, but we're going to have to get to heat eventually. (High latitude specific of course).

7/ We should design new systems with behaviour change in mind rather than as like for like replacement. People use gas boilers the way they do because that's how boilers work â€“ it doesn't mean that future heat technologies need to work like gas boilers.

8/ Future smart energy systems will collect and use much more personal and private data. We need to have conversations about what that looks like and whether it will put people off participating in services that will be good for the energy system.

9/ Consumer interaction with energy systems will need interfaces that are as enjoyable and inuitive as the best designed apps now. Just because an app is made by an  energy utility rather than a software company, that doesn't let them off the hook in terms of UX.

10/ Most of us will never change our behaviour significantly enough, in large enough volumes and in the right way to positively affect energy systems. That will need well-designed and powerful incentives baked into the services we use.

11/ Nuclear fusion will continue to not be a thing for many decades to come. Sorry. 

Though we should keep developing it, because one day it will work and it's part of the critical path to becoming a Kardashev Type I civilisation. And that's the point of all this, no?

12/ Our idea of what 'in control' looks like will keep changing, moving from static to dynamic equilibrium.

In the past, we could flex energy supply to match known and slow-changing demand. In the future, both supply and demand will change quickly and will be hard to forecast.

13/ Carbon sequestration will play a major role in reducing emissions from fossil fuels and contribute to net flows of carbon out of the atmpsphere through Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage (BECCS).
14/ Coal power is already dead. That truth is just unevenly distributed.

15/ The emergence of long duration, low cost energy storage technologies will finally decouple us from the need to use electricity the moment it is generated. This will allow us to better integrate and deploy more renewable energy.

16/ I don't believe that 'at lowest cost' should necessarily be the top driver for energy systems. A resilient low carbon  system may simply be more expensive to build than a high carbon one that breaks easily. 

Vulnerable people should still be protected from high bills though.

17/ (UK) Whatever your views on whether utilities should be public or private, I think nationalisation would have been a bad idea, if only for the level of distraction it would have introduced. 

Executives and staff have limited attention - let's keep it on the transformation.

18/ Most people are unlikely to change how they engage with the energy systems unless they get a higher quality of service for a similar or lower price. 

For example, energy efficient homes need to be nicer and cheaper to live in than leaky homes.

19/ Today we buy energy as a commodity: electricity, gas. In the future we'll buy a service: heating, cooling, lighting and the vector will be irrelevant.

This shift will give utilities more freedom to play with new business models and improve the quality of service we receive.

20/ Many challenges around energy system transformation have nothing to do with innovation or tech. The reasons it's hard to renovate homes today are the same as 20 years ago: fragmented supply chains, split incentives between tenants and landlords and lack of skills.

21/ We need to think further ahead than just the next innovation. We've caught on that electric vehicles are going to be disruptive to power systems, but we're hardly thinking about autonomous electric vehicles or urban trends away from car ownership at all.

22/ There is a tension between how electricity networks (natural monopolies) are regulated and what actions they take. Technology has only ever required more assets to be built - cables, transformers - but now we have 'non-wires alternatives'. Regulation is still catching up.

23/ We need to tell better stories about the role of energy networks. We talk constraint management, voltage support, frequency response, inertia emulation (and tigers, oh my). 

Most issues are too complex to describe simply, but the more we try, the more consumers will engage.

24/ Innovation is not R&D. Innovation is not R&D. Transformation of the energy system will need continued "market pull" for deployable tech, "technology push" for early stage tech, and well designed support mechanisms to progress from one to the other.

https://t.co/CMvya7FCnz

25/ Many of the business cases for future energy technologies depend on unlocking 'shared value'. There's value to be had from fixing a system-wide inefficiency, but it's hard to capture by a single asset or asset class. Batteries are a prime example of this.

26/ Net zero will give forward-thinking energy companies the chance to totally reinvent themselves.

A great example is @Draxnews, formerly (I believe) the UK's single largest CO2  emitter, now the world's first company to aim for net negative emissions.

https://t.co/ZL1OaAGMtb

27/ Climate change will change patterns of demand for energy. 

Traditionally, the lowest demand for electricity in Europe has been summer days, as air conditioning isn't common. 

As climate change increases summer temperatures, though, air conditioning use will rise.

28/ Although, reliable use of air conditioning can be useful for grid management. 

Turning off an AC unit for 15 minutes won't affect the temperature of a house much, but doing it across 10,000 homes is a huge cut in energy.

Perfect on a cloudy day when solar PV fluctuates.

29/ Which brings me on to demand management. 

In the past we could flex supply to meet demand, we can increasingly flex demand to balance intermittent supply.

Vehicles, AC, heating, appliances can all flex their demand intelligently to help the network.

https://t.co/x0lcMkdmir

30/ This is a key new area for innovation and opportunity for startups: aggregation.

Aggregators build huge portfolios of energy assets, apply clever analytics and controls, and sell managed access to portfolios to big utilities. We'll see more of this.

https://t.co/t68Ih2OdGh

31/ Aggregators are interesting because they can capture huge value with minimal infrastructure of their own. 

They don't need to build, own or maintain network, but add a layer of intelligence and control to the network. They also compete with each other, so innovate faster.
